abstract.text: An object that defines the relationships between calendar units (such as eras, years, and weekdays) and absolute points in time, providing features for calculation and comparison of dates.
An object that defines the relationships between calendar units (such as eras, years, and weekdays) and absolute points in time, providing features for calculation and comparison of dates.
Returns a date representing the absolute time calculated from given components.
Returns a date representing the absolute time calculated by adding given components to a given date.
An object that specifies a date or time in terms of units (such as year, month, day, hour, and minute) to be evaluated in a calendar system and time zone.
Returns the date components representing a given date.
Returns the difference between two supplied dates as date components.
Calendrical units such as year, month, day and hour.

inlineContent.text: objects encapsulate information about systems of reckoning time in which the beginning, length, and divisions of a year are defined. They provide information about the calendar and support for calendrical computations such as determining the range of a given calendrical unit and adding units to a given absolute time.

inlineContent.text: Most locales use the most widely used civil calendar, called the
Gregorian calendar
), but there remain exceptions to this trend. For example:
In Saudi Arabia, some locales use primarily the Islamic Umm al-Qura calendar (
In Ethiopia, some locales use primarily the Ethiopian calendar (
or
In Iran and Afghanistan, some locales use primarily the Persian calendar (
In Thailand, some locales use primarily the Buddhist calendar (
Other locales use another calendar alongside the Gregorian calendar. For example:
India also uses the Indian national calendar (
Israel also uses the Hebrew calendar (
China mainland and other regions also use the Chinese calendar (
), primarily to calculate astronomical date and Chinese traditional holidays.
Japan also uses the Japanese calendar (
), primarily to add year names.
Independent of any particular locale, certain calendars are used primarily to calculate dates for religious observances. Among these are the Buddhist (
), Coptic (
), Hebrew (
), and Islamic (
) calendars.

content.text: How NSCalendar Models the Gregorian Calendar

inlineContent.text: The Gregorian calendar was first introduced in 1582, as a replacement for the Julian Calendar. According to the Julian calendar, a leap day is added to February for any year with a number divisible by 4, which results in an annual disparity of 11 minutes, or 1 day every 128 years. The Gregorian calendar revised the rules for leap day calculation, by skipping the leap day for any year with a number divisible by 100, unless that year number is also divisible by 400, resulting in an annual disparity of only 26 seconds, or 1 day every 3323 years.
To transition from the Julian calendar to the Gregorian calendar, 10 days were dropped from the Gregorian calendar (October 5–14).

After the Gregorian calendar was introduced, many regions continued to use the Julian calendar, with Turkey being the last country or region to adopt the Gregorian calendar, in 1926. As a result of the staggered adoption, the transition period for regions at the time of adoption have different start dates and a different number of skipped days to account for the additional disparity from leap day calculations.
models the behavior of a
proleptic
Gregorian calendar (
as defined by ISO 8601:2004

), which extends the Gregorian calendar backward in time from the date of its introduction. This behavior should be taken into account when working with dates created before the transition period of the affected locales.
To do calendar arithmetic, you use

objects in conjunction with a calendar. For example, to convert between a decomposed date in one calendar and another calendar, you must first convert the decomposed elements into a date using the first calendar, then decompose it using the second.
provides the absolute scale and epoch (reference point) for dates and times, which can then be rendered into a particular calendar, for calendrical computations or user display.
Two
methods that return a date object,
, take as a parameter an

object that describes the calendrical components required for the computation. You can provide as many components as you need (or choose to). When there is incomplete information to compute an absolute time, default values similar to
and

are usually chosen by a calendar, but this is a calendar-specific choice. If you provide inconsistent information, calendar-specific disambiguation is performed (which may involve ignoring one or more of the parameters). Related methods (
and
) take a bit mask parameter that specifies which components to calculate when returning an
object. The bit mask is composed of
constants (see

In a calendar, day, week, weekday, month, and year numbers are generally 1-based, but there may be calendar-specific exceptions. Ordinal numbers, where they occur, are 1-based. Some calendars represented by this API may have to map their basic unit concepts into year/month/week/day/… nomenclature. For example, a calendar composed of 4 quarters in a year instead of 12 months uses the month unit to represent quarters. The particular values of the unit are defined by each calendar, and are not necessarily consistent with values for that unit in another calendar.
